Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A coalescent analysis of the diversity of standing genetic variation and adaptive evolution in the threespine stickleback
Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolution by natural selection is thought to often take thousands or millions of years. The environments in which species live can change drastically on much shorter timescales, however, and species must adapt quickly or risk extinction. Along the west coast of the US and Canada, a small fish species, the threespine stickleback, is known to adapt within decades to wildly different environments. This study will examine how stickleback achieve this feat by focusing on the influence a species' gene pool has on its ability to respond rapidly to a changing environment. Specifically, the proposed research will examine (1) how much of adaptive evolution is aided by genetic variation already existing in the stickleback gene pool, and (2) how the stickleback's history of adaptation has influenced the organization of genetic variation in its entire genome. This understanding of adaptive potential is crucial to our ability to predict how species and ecosystems will respond to future environmental shifts, and thus has implications for conservation and game management efforts, climate change mitigation, and agriculture.

Standing genetic variation is the pool of available genetic variants in a population available for evolutionary change. Recent research, facilitated by next-generation DNA sequencing technologies and new analytical techniques, has revitalized the debate over the relative influence of standing genetic variation versus new mutation on adaptive evolution and speciation. The research funded by this grant will use approaches based in coalescent theory, a mathematically-rigorous approach at the interface of phylogenetics and population genetics, to understand the prevalence and influence of standing variation in natural populations of threespine stickleback fish. By combining restriction site-associated DNA sequencing, a powerful method for genome-wide inference, with new long-read sequencing capabilities, the proposed research will generate data-rich genealogies at tens of thousands of loci and provide unprecedented detail into adaptation of natural populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our understanding of evolution has improved dramatically over the past fifty years. Of the many discoveries made in that time, few have been as influential as the observation that organisms can evolve rapidly, sometimes within just a few generations, when environmental conditions change. Biologists can directly observe populations of a species change physically and genetically in response to changes to their environments. However, adaptation requires genetic variation so that those individuals with the best fit to the new environment can pass those traits on to their offspring. Where does that variation come from? How is it present in a population even before an environment changes? With the support of this grant, we have used next-generation DNA sequencing technologies and developed new techniques to address these questions using the threespine stickleback fish as an exemplar of rapid adaptation to environmental change. Threespine stickleback live throughout the coastal oceans and neighboring lakes and river systems of the Northern Hemisphere. Many of these freshwater populations have evolved recently— even within the past fifty years. We have found that, unlike the fish populations themselves, the genetic variation fueling recent adaptation evolved long ago. Many of the gene variants evolved millions of years ago, perhaps even before the threespine stickleback existed as the species we recognize today. Moreover, this genetic variation is concentrated in certain regions of the stickleback genome, such that nearby marine and freshwater stickleback look like distinct species in some genomic regions, while in others they are indistinguishable. We have discovered that these important genetic variants persist because stickleback have been continually evolving in both freshwater and marine habitats that entire time. Our findings demonstrate that the pace and predictability of adaptation are products of evolution happening over multiple timescales — from decades to millions of years. During the completion of this grant, a graduate student and undergraduate both obtained extensive experience in modern genomic technologies, and also developed a new approach for assaying the history of genetic variation. This novel technique be useful for other scientists as well as many private sector industries. In summary, the populations of fish we study are evolving at a surprising rate, but that is only possible because their genes and genomes have been continually evolving over many millions of years, honing the stickleback’s ability to switch predictably between environments.
